title: Understanding and altering perceptions of personal 'invulnerability' to persuasive advertising
abstractText:
Persuasion is an inescapable feature of life. Interestingly however, research shows that while people generally feel that others will be influenced by persuasive media (eg advertising), they believe that they themselves will not be influenced. Because this tendency to evaluate the self more positively than others is both logically and statistically suspect, it is seen as a self-serving bias. The aim of the present research is to test and extend current theories of why this bias occurs.

One theory proposes that it makes people feel good about themselves to believe that others are more susceptible to advertising. For example, perceiving oneself as invulnerable to persuasive advertising may increase self-esteem and positive self-regard. Another theory proposes that people generally think differently about their own and others’ behaviour. For example, when thinking about the self people may apply knowledge of their own personal characteristics (eg intelligence) that make them invulnerable. On the other hand, they may apply more objective information (eg knowledge of sales figures) in making their judgements of others.

In four experiments we aim to test these possible explanations. In doing so, we hope to understand the psychological processes involved in judging one’s own and others’ susceptibility to persuasive influence.
